text: The dense, lush rain forests of the eastern slopes of the Andes, the place known as "The Eyebrow of the Jungle". Ra jutting canyon walls are half-hidden by the thick mists. The MAIN TITLE is followed by this:

A narrow trail across the green face of the canyon. A gro of men make their way along it. At the head of the party an American, INDIANA JONES. He wears a short leather jack a flapped holster, and a brimmed felt hat with a weird fe stuck in the band. Behind him come two Spanish Peruvians, SATIPO and BARRANCA. Bringing up the rear are five Yagua  INDIANS. They act as porters and are wrangling the two he packed llamas. The Indians become increasingly nervous. T speak to each other in bursts of Quechua. The American, w is known to his friends as Indy, glances back at them.
(irritated) They're talking about the Curse again!

He turns and yells at the Indians in Quechua, his anger g an indication of his own fears. The party reaches a break the canyon wall and takes the trail through it. When they emerge, their destination is revealed to them i the distance. Beyond a thick stand of trees is the vegeta enshrouded TEMPLE OF THE CHACHAPOYAN WARRIORS. The entire party is struck by the sight. The Indians,  terrified now, chatter away. Suddenly the three at the ba turn and run, dropping their packs as they go. Barranca y at the fleeing Indians and pulls his pistol out. He start to raise his arm to aim but Indy restrains it in a muscul grip.
sense_profile: to raise his arm to aim

text: No.
Barranca looks evilly at Indy's hand upon him. Indy relea him and smiles in a friendly way.
We don't need them.
Satipo watches this confrontation with some concern.
I do not carry supplies.
We'll leave them. Once we've got it,  we'll be able to reach the plane by  dusk.

He turns back to the trail. Satipo gets the two remaining Indians moving behind Indy. Satipo and Barranca then have fast, silent communication: Barranca indicates his desire slit Indy's throat; Satipo gives him a look that says "Be patient, you idiot".
sense_profile: the two remaining Indians moving behind Indy

text: The party fans out to fight their way through the entwine trees that guard the temple. Visibility is cut to five fe in the heavy mist. Satipo extracts a short, native dart f a tree and examines the point gingerly
(showing Indy) The Hovitos are near. The poison is  still fresh... three days. They're  following us, I tell you.
If they knew we were here, they would  have killed us already.

The two Indiana jabber in Quechua, near hysteria. Barranc is sweating profusely, eyes darting. He yells at the Indi in Quechua to "shut up". In the undergrowth, there is slithering movement. Indian #1 draws aside a branch and is faced with a horrif stone sculpture of a Chachapoyan demon. The Indian is so  frightened no sound comes out when he screams. He turns a runs silently away. Indian #2 calls to his friend. Getting no response, he st in that direction. A huge macaw, flushed from the undergr screams and flies away. Indian #2 does exactly the same t never to be seen again. Indy, Satipo and Barranca, just clearing the trees, look  back in that direction. They all turn to face the Temple. It is dark and awesome. Vegetation curls from every crevi over each elaborate frieze. The entrance - round, open an black - has been designed to look like open jaws.
sense_profile: A huge macaw , flushed from the undergr screams and

text: So this is where Forrestal cashed  in.
A friend of yours?
Competitor. He was good, very good.
(nervous) No one has ever come out of there  alive. Why should we put our faith  in you?

Indy takes the weird feather from the band of his hat. Fr around its point, he slips a tightly rolled piece of  parchment. Barranca and Satipo exchange a quick "So that' where is was!" look. They all kneel as Indy spreads out t parchment. On it is one-half of a crude floorplan of the  Temple.
sense_profile: from the band of his hat

text: No one ever had what we have...  partners.

Indy fixes them with an expectant stare. Satipo produces similar, but folded, piece of parchment. He lays it - the other half of the floorplan - next to Indy's. They all re it for a moment, then Indy stands and walks toward the Te Barranca's eyes are shining as they dart between the floo and Satipo.
(back turned) Assuming that pillar there marks the  corner and...

Barranca is suddenly on his feet, quietly drawing his pis He raises it toward Indy as Satipo realizes with alarm wh he's doing. Too late. Indy's head turns and he sees Barra Indy's next move is amazing, graceful and fast, yet total unhurried. His right hand slides up under the back of his leather jacket and emerges grasping the handle of a neatl curled bullwhip. With the same fluid move that brings Ind body around to face the Peruvian, the whip uncoils to its full ten foot length and flashes out. The fall of the whip (the unplaited strip at the end of t lash) wraps itself around Barranca's hand and pistol. He  could not drop the gun now if he tried. Indy gives the whip a short pull and Barranca's arm in je down, where it involuntarily discharges the gun into the  dirt. Barranca is amazed, but feels some slack in the whi and immediately raises the gun toward Indy again, cocking with his free hand. Indy's face goes hard. And sad. Indy sweeps his arm in a wide arc. Barranca spins around, enclosed in the whip, his gun hand stuck tight against hi body. Indy gives one more short jerk on the whip handle a Barranca's gun fires. Barranca falls dead. Indy looks quickly at Satipo, who is shocked and frighten He raises his arms in supplication.
sense_profile: the whip uncoils to its full ten foot length and
a short pull and Barranca 's arm
one more short jerk on the whip

text: I knew nothing! He was crazy! Please!
Indy looks him over, then nods. He frees the whip from  Barranca's body and picks up the man. His eyes sweep the  surrounding woods.
Let's go.

Indy and Satipo, carrying a torch, walk up the slightly  inclined, tubular passage from the main entrance. The int is wet and dark, hanging with plant life and stalactites. Their echoing footsteps intermittently overpower the soun of loud dripping, whistling air drafts and scampering cla

Indy leads the way down a twisting hallway, Satipo's torc barely lighting his way from behind. Indy disappears in a shadow and when he reappears a moment later a huge black  tarantula is crawling up the back of his jacket. Indy doe notice and disappears into another shadow, emerging with more tarantulas on his back. Satipo sees them and makes a frightened grunting sound. I looks at him, sees what he's pointing at and casually bru all three spiders off with his rolled whip, as he would a fly. Satipo pirouettes for an inspection and Indy flicks off the Peruvian's back. Indy begins picking up little pocket-sized artifacts from the niches and ledges of the Temple. He continues to do t as the men penetrate the Temple. His collecting is quick expert, evaluating the pieces in an instant, discarding s stuffing others into his clothes, and never stopping his  forward progress.
sense_profile: the way down a twisting hallway , Satipo 's torc barely lighting his way from behind
what he 's pointing at and casually
picking up little pocket - sized artifacts from the niches and ledges of the Temple

text: The men reach an arch in the hall. The small chamber ahea which interrupts the hall, is brightly lit by a shaft of  sunlight from high above. Indy stops, looks it over.
What's wrong? Are you lost?

Indy picks up a stick and throws it through the shaft of  light. Giant spikes spring together from the sides of the chamber with a ferocious CLANG! And impaled on the spikes are the remains of a white man, half-fleshed, half skelet in explorer-type grab. Indy reaches out and takes hold of the man's carcass. As the spikes slowly retract, Indy pul it free and seats the remains gently on the floor.
Forrestal.
(gulps) We can go no further.
Now, Satipo, we don't want to be  discouraged by every little thing.

Indy steps sideways into the chamber. His back pressed ag the very points of the retracted spikes, he moves along t edge of the light beam, and steps clear on the other side Satipo grimaces and begins sweating his way through.
sense_profile: along t edge of the light beam
His back pressed ag the very points of the retracted spikes

text: Indy and Satipo come down stone stairs to a tight landing Framing the entry are a carefully strung network of dead  vines, each somehow hooked into the wall, narrowing the  opening even more.
sense_profile: are a carefully strung network of dead vines

text: (taking torch) Let me see that.

He lowers the torch to the floor of the landing. The land is carpeted with human skeletons, one on top of another, squashed flat as cardboard. Satipo gasps. Indy looks up a the ceiling of the landing, then steps onto skeletons, wh make a cracking noise under his feet.
sense_profile: to the floor of the landing
a the ceiling of the landing

text: Try not to touch the vines.
The men are in a high, straight hallway 50 feet long. The door at the end is flooded with sunlight.
Senor, I think we are very close.
Indy stands still looking at the hall.
(impatient) Let us hurry. There is nothing to  fear here.
That's what scares me.

They begin walking down the hall side by side. Satipo has inched a little ahead. Suddenly his lead foot comes down through the floor! As Satipo begins to pitch forward, Ind grabs him by the belt and pulls him back. They both look  down at the "floor". Indy swings his whip across the floor. Fifteen feet of it cuts open beneath the lash, falling away to reveal black as wide as the hall. The illusory floor was made of dust- covered cobwebs. Satipo picks up a stone and drops it dow the pit. No sound. The two men exchange glances. Indy loo up at the high roof of the hall. He swings the whip up ar a support beam, tests its strength with a pull and swings over the pit on the whip. From the other side he swings t whip back to Satipo, who throws Indy the torch. Satipo sw across. When they are both standing on solid floor there a moment of quiet in which they hear, from far, far below SPLASH! Indy wedges the whip handle into the wall and lea it strung to the beam for quick retreat.

A large, domed room. Ten evenly-spaced skylights send the shafts of sunlight down to a unique tiled floor: white an black tiles laid out in a lovely, intricate pattern. Indy and Satipo stand at the door and look across the wide roo at the altar. There, in the supreme hallowed spot, is a t jeweled figurine, Indy's real objective. Two torches, many years old, are in holders by the door.  Indy takes one down and lights it. He gives the regular t to Satipo.
There's plenty of light, amigo.

Indy kneels and uses the unlit end of the torch to reach and tap a white tile. It is solid. He taps a black tile.  There is a whizzing sound and a tiny dark sticks in the t Satipo points to the wall nearby: there is a recessed hol there.
sense_profile: the unlit end of the torch
a whizzing sound and a tiny dark sticks in the t Satipo

text: From that hole!
Indy nods, stands and looks around the sanctuary. The ent room is honey-comed with the same kind of hole. Satipo se it too and is properly impressed.
You wait here.
If you insist, senor.

Torch in hand, Indy begins his careful walk across the  sanctuary. Stepping only on the white tiles, he almost ap to be doing a martial arts kata. Before each big move he  waves the torch in front of him head to toe, looking at t flame. Halfway out, he sees something on the floor and kn to look at it. A dead bird lies on one of the white tiles. Its body is  riddled with little deadly darts. This has great signific to Indy and he stands with even greater caution. He waves the torch ahead of him and at waist height an air current whips at the flame. Indy ducks under it and leaves a burn mark on the white tile beneath it. Satipo watches, wide-eyed and mystified. Indy reaches the altar. The tiny idol looks both fierce a beautiful. It rests on a pedestal of polished stone. Indy looks the whole set-up over very carefully. From his jack he takes a small, canvas drawstring bad. He begins fillin it with dirt from around the case of the altar. When he h created a weight that he thinks approximates the weight o the idol, he bounces it a couple times in his palm  concentrating. It's clear he wants to replace the idol wi the bag as smoothly as possible. His hand seems ready to that once, when he stops, takes a breath and loosens his  shoulder muscles. Now he sets himself again. And makes th switch! The idol is now in his hand, the bag on the pedes For a long moment it sits there, then the polished stone  beneath the bag drops five inches. This sets off an AURAL CHAIN REACTION of steadily increasing volume as some huge mysterious mechanism rumbles into action deep in the temp Indy spins and starts his kata back across the sanctuary four times the speed. Satipo's eyes widen in terror. He turns and runs.
sense_profile: his careful walk across the sanctuary
on one of the white tiles
on a pedestal of polished stone
fillin it with dirt from around the case of the altar
approximates the weight o the idol
to replace the idol wi the bag as smoothly as possible

text: The sanctuary has begun to rumble and shake in response t the mysterious mechanism. Just as Indy goes out the door, rock shakes loose from the wall and rolls onto the tiles  floor. Immediately, a noisy torrent of poison darts fills the room.
sense_profile: a noisy torrent of poison darts

text: Satipo swings across the pit. He makes it just as the whi comes undone from the beam, leaving Indy without an escap Satipo, extremely nervous, regards the whip a moment then turns back to face Indy, who has run up to the far side o the pit.
sense_profile: back to face Indy , who has run up to the far side o the pit

text: No time to argue. Throw me the idol,  I throw you the whip.
Indy hesitates, eyeing the rumbling walls.
You have no choice! Hurry!
Indy concurs with that assessment. He tosses the idol acr the pit to Satipo. Satipo stuffs it in the front pocket o his jacket, gives Indy a look, then drops the whip on the floor and runs.
Adios, amigo!
Indy grimaces. He had a feeling this might happen. He loo around.
Satipo flies through like a chubby ballet dancer and take the steps five at a time.
sense_profile: through like a chubby ballet dancer

text: Indy runs in full stride to the edge of the pit and broad jumps into space. He doesn't make it. His body hits the f side of the pit and he begins to slide out of view. Only  wild clawing with his fingers at the edge of the pit stop his descent. With just the tips of his fingers over the e he begins pulling himself up.
sense_profile: Only wild clawing with his fingers at the edge of the pit

text: Satipo has slowed down. He begins to edge carefully aroun the light shaft.

Indy sails through sideways and rolls to a stop at the bo of the steps. His whip is grasped in his hand. As he rais himself, he hears, from above the giant spikes of the Cha of Light CLANG! and an abrupt, sickening rendition of SAT LAST SCREAM. Indy runs up the steps. The rumbling sound g louder.

Indy slides to a stop. The spikes have retracted, taking  Satipo's body to one side. Indy edges into the chamber wi his back to the shaft of light. Soon he is face to face w the dead Satipo; spikes protrude from several vital spots the Peruvian's body. Indy removes the idol from Satipo's  pocket and moves quickly out the other side.
Adios.

Indy shoots out of a cut-off hallway and turns toward the exit. The rumbling is very loud and now we see why: right behind Indy a huge boulder comes roaring around a corner the passage, perfectly form-fitted to the passageway. It  obliterates everything before it, sending the stalactites shooting ahead like missiles. Indy dashes for the light o the exit. His hat flies off his head. Almost immediately is crushed by the boulder. Indy dives out the end of the  passage as the boulder slams to a perfect fit at the entr sealing the Temple.
sense_profile: out of a cut - off hallway

text: Indy lies on the ground, gasping for air. A shadow falls  across him and he looks up.

Looming above him are three figures. Two are HOVITOS WARR in full battle paint and loin cloths. They carry long blo guns. But the man in the center draws Indy's attention. H is a tall, impressive white man, dressed in full safari o including pith helmet. His name is EMILE BELLOQ. His face thin, powerful; his eyes hypnotic; his smile charming, ye lethal. His heavily French-accented speech is deep,  mellifluous, wonderful. Back beyond Belloq and his two  escorts, thirty more Hovitos Warriors hover at the edge o the trees.
Dr. Jones, you choose the wrong  friends. This time it will cost you.
Belloq extends his hand. Indy looks at it, then produces idol and hands it to Belloq. Belloq extends his other han smiling. Indy hands over his gun. Belloq sticks it in his jacket.
And you thought I'd given up.
(eyeing the Hovitos) Too bad they don't know you like I  do, Belloq.
(smiles) Yes, too bad. You could warn them...  if only you spoke Hovitos.

With that, Belloq turns dramatically and holds the idol h for all the Hovitos to see and says something in Hovitos. There is a murmur of recognition and all the Indians,  including Belloq's escorts, prostrate themselves upon the ground, heads down. Indy is immediately up and running toward the edge of the clearing.
(in Hovitos) Kill him!

head_text.subj: AT THE EDGE OF THE CLEARING

text: Indy disappears into the foliage. An instant later, the l are peppered with a rain of poison darts and spears.
Indy runs like hell through steadily falling terrain. And always close behind, a swift gang of angry Hovitos.  Occasionally they get close enough to send a dart or spea whizzing past Indy's head.
sense_profile: close enough to send a dart or spea

text: An amphibian plane sits in the water beneath a green clif Sitting on the wing is JOCK, the British pilot. Indy brea out of some distant brush and runs along the path at the of the cliff.
sense_profile: along the path at the of the cliff

text: (yelling) Get it going! Get it going!
Jock hops in and fires up the plane's engines. Indy reach a spot on the cliff above the place, glances back, them j into the river. He comes up, swims to the plane and grabs strut.
sense_profile: a spot on the cliff above the place

text: GO!
Jock starts the plane moving across the water as Indy wal across the wing and falls into the passenger compartment.

Indy relaxes and lies across the seat, a big smile on his face. One hand drops to the floor of the cabin and Indy j hitting his head. On the floor of the cabin is a huge boa constrictor. Indy tries to get his whole body onto the se Jock sees what's happening.
sense_profile: to get his whole body onto the se

text: Don't mind him. That's Reggie.  Wouldn't hurt a soul.
I can't stand snakes.
The world's full of them, you know.
I hate them.
Come on now, Sport, show a little of  the old backbone.
It soars off over the dark jungle.

It's autumn and the pretty, New England campus out Indy's window reflects it in dazzling color. A few weeks before start of classes. Activity just picking up. Some students about. Indy is at a bookcase near the window and he looks quite  different in this setting. His outfit is tweedy, slightly rumpled in the professional style. Part of his attention focused in a book and he wears glasses to see the fine pr The office is cramped, absolutely inundated with books, m etchings and archeological artifacts. In fact, the only n spot in the room right now is Indy's desk, which has been cleared off expressly for the benefit of -

The Curator of the National Museum in Washington, D.C. Br is examining the small artifacts Indy pocketed on his way into the Peruvian Temple. He occasionally uses a jeweler' eyepiece to get a closer look. But he is distracted, his  concerns elsewhere, and it is this that his old friend In senses from across the room.
Do you think the idol will ever show  up?
I don't know. Just because Belloq  had it doesn't mean he kept it.

Indy snaps the book closed and puts it on the shelf. He t his glasses off and focuses on Brody. At the windowed doo to his office, two pretty Coeds pause for a moment, look at their sexy Archeology professor, giggle and disappear.
sense_profile: at their sexy Archeology professor , giggle and disappear

text: Getting it away from those Indians  would be a neat trick (a hard look) I hope they got him.
A young male graduate student, Indy's TEACHING ASSISTANT, taps on the door and then pushes his way in with an armlo of reference books. Indy helps him find a spot for them.
I couldn't get the McNabe, Professor.  Someone's got it checked out 'til  next month when classes start.
That's all right, Phil. Thanks a  lot.
(eager to please) Will there be anything else?
No. I'll see you Thursday.
The Teaching Assistant leaves. Brody is scowling as he  examines the last of the artifacts.
Hey, if you don't like them, I can  always return them.
No, they're beautiful. The Museum  will buy them as usual. No questions  asked.
Then what's wrong?
I brought along some people today.
What kind of people?
Government.
(concerned) Government?
Don't worry, it's not about your  business. (indicates the  artifacts) They're from the Army.
I've already served.
Army Intelligence. They're looking  for Abner.

Indy's course - a combination of archeology and anthropol is taught in this amphitheater-type lecture hall. His des and lectern hold large reference books; blackboards line wall. Bones, maps, charts festoon the walls. Indy leans against his desk talking with Brody and two  uniformed Army officers, COLONEL MUSGROVE and MAJOR EATON who are situated around the first seats in the classroom.
But you did study under Professor  Ravenwood at the University of  Chicago?
(nods) We haven't spoken in ten years. I'm  afraid we had a bit of a falling  out.
You know nothing of his whereabouts?
(negative) Just rumors. Somewhere in Asia, last  I heard.
Musgrove and Eaton exchange a look; they're disappointed.
(to Musgrove) Maybe Dr. Jones can make sense of  it.
Again the military men have a silent communication, decid what to reveal.
Well... you must understand, Dr.  Jones, this is all strictly  confidential.
I understand.
Yesterday, one of our European  sections intercepted a Nazi communique  from Cairo to Berlin. We don't quite  know what to make of it.
Musgrove takes a sheet from his briefcase.
Here it is - "Tanis development  proceeding. Acquire headpiece, Staff  of Ra, General Tengtu Hok, Shanghai.  Locate Abner Ravenwood, U.S."
Brody is excited. He looks at Indy.
Tanis. They must have discovered the  lost ruins.
Indy contemplates this big news; he's impressed.
(to himself) Tanis. Ain't that somethin'!
Frankly, we're a little suspicious...  An American being mentioned so  prominently in a secret Nazi cable.
Ah, Ravenwood's no Nazi.
Then what do they want him for?
They're looking for the headpiece to  the Staff of Ra.
(indicates his sheet) But it says here that's in China.
Only half of it. Ravenwood had the  other half.
What would the Nazis want with this -  this Staff of Ra?
I can tell you that. Over the last  two years the Nazis have had teams  of archeologists running around the  world looking for all kinds of  religious artifacts.
That's right. Hitler's a nut on the  subject. Crazy. He's obsessed with  the occult.
What is this Staff of Ra, anyway?
It all has to do with the Ark of the  Covenant. (the Army guys look  mystified) The chest the Hebrews used to carry  around the Ten Commandments.
Now it's the Army men who are impressed.

An Egyptian pharaoh stole the Ark  from Jerusalem and took it back to  the city of Tanis. A short time later,  Tanis was consumed by the desert in  a sandstorm that lasted a year. But  before that, the Pharaoh had had the  Ark hidden away in a secret chamber  called the Well of the Souls. Which  is where the Staff of Ra comes in.
Indy moves to the blackboard and makes a quick sketch to  give a rough idea of the system as he describes it. (and get a glimpse of what an interesting and enthusiastic tea he must be).
sense_profile: a rough idea of the system
a glimpse of what an interesting and enthusiastic tea he must be

text: Now this was rather clever. The Staff  was really just a big stick - oh, I  don't know, say like this - (he indicates about  six feet) no one really knows for sure. Any  way, it was capped by an elaborate  headpiece with a carving of the sun  at the top. What you had to do was  take the Staff to a special map room  in Tanis - it had the whole city  laid out in miniature on the floor.  When you placed the Staff in a certain  spot in this room, at a certain time  of day, the sun would shine through  a hole here in the headpiece and  then send a beam of light down here -  to the map - giving you the location  of the Well of the Souls...
...where the Ark of the Covenant was  kept.
(nods) Which is probably what the Nazis are  after.
What's this Ark look like?
Look like? Why, it's right here...
Indy pulls a big format book from the stack on his lecter and flips through the pages until he finds a large color  print. The other men gather to look.

Fills the screen. It shows a Biblical battle. The Israelite Army is vanquis an opposition force. At the forefront of the Israelite ra two men carry the Ark of the Covenant, a beautiful gold c crowned by two sculptured gold angels. The men do not tou the Ark itself; rather they carry it by use of two long w poles which pass through rings in the corners of the Ark. The painting is very dramatic, full of smoke, tumult and  sinewy dying men. But the most astounding thing in the pi is the brilliant jet of white light and flame issuing fro the wings of the angels. It pierces deep into the ranks o the retreating enemy, wreaking devastation and terror.
Good God!
Yes. That's what the Hebrews thought.
What's that supposed to be coming  out of there?
Who knows... lightning... fire...  the power of God.
I'm beginning to understand Hitler's  interest in this thing.

Oh yes. The Bible tells of it leveling  mountains and wasting entire regions.  Moses promised that when the Ark was  with you, "your enemies will be  scattered and your foes fell before  you". (pause) An army which carries the Ark before  it is invincible.
Eaton and Musgrove exchange worried looks.
Oh, there's one other thing that  Hitler undoubtably believes about  the Ark... (a long pregnant pause) It's said that the Lost Ark will be  recovered at the time of the coming  of the True Messiah.
Dr. Jones, you've been very helpful.  I hope we can call on you again if  we have questions.
Most certainly.
Brody and Indy exchange a look as they all shake and Brod starts to leave with the Army men.

Indy's English Tudor, upper middle class home. Quite tone well beyond the financial reach of an honest college  professor. Marcus Brody has already rung the bell. Indy o the door. He is dressed in a tuxedo.
I've got to talk to you.
This isn't really a good time.
Indy, it's important.
All right. Come on in.
The lush tone continues here in Art Deco and shiny marble Indy motions Brody toward the study to one side.
I'll be in a minute.
As Brody passes the entrance to the expansive living room he spots a beautiful, silk-gowned Harlow-type lounging on the sofa in front of a roaring fire. She is sipping champ

Brody enters the book-lined, dark-wooded study. He paces a moment before the fire which is dying in the fireplace, then spots something and goes over to Indy's big desk. Th surface is covered with open books, monographs, maps and  drawings - all about the Ark of the Covenant. Brody smile he knows his friend very well. Indy comes in, closing the door behind him. Brody turns to him with a triumphant  expression.
They want you to go for it. And  they'll pay.
(smiles) Good work, Marcus. I had a feeling  this would happen. And, of course,  the Museum gets the Ark when we're  done.
(smiles) Of course.
Indy's manner is vigorous, aggressive.
Okay, here's the way it's gonna be.  First, I'll high-tail it to Shanghai  and get the piece from General Hok.  Then I think I know where I can find  Ravenwood. If only I can get -
General Hok's a tough customer. They  don't call him the Wild Boar for  nothing. And he's tied in with the  Japanese.
I'll worry about that when the time  comes. My only hope is to find the  Well of the Souls before the Nazis  do.
A Pan Am Clipper flies west over the Pacific.

Indy is barely into the front seat of a dilapidated Ford the driver, BUZZ KEHOE, is peeling out into traffic. In t back seat is a Chinese named BANG CHOW. Kehoe zigs crazil through traffic with only his left hand as he reaches ove to shake with Indy.
Buzz Kehoe, Army Intelligence. You've  met Bang Chow.
What's the hurry?
Some German agents got here two hours  ago. Luckily, Bang was able to have  them detained at Customs. We'll have  to hurry.

Kehoe's car emerges from an alley. Down the block is Teng Hok's modest, walled palace. Kehoe's car slows a bit and  Bang steps from the moving car with a small black suitcas in his hand. While he heads down the street toward Hok's  place, Kehoe's car continues across the street and into a alley on the other side.
A Mercedes limousine appears round a corner and squeals t stop at the front gate of the palace, which is manned by sturdy Chinese Gateman. There are three Germans inside, o the driver.

Kehoe, alone now, pushes a trash container casually into  position to hide a newly created hole in the rear wall of Hok's Museum where several stone blocks have been removed He looks around and ambles back to the car.

The three Germans wait impatiently in a magnificent foyer chime sounds and huge double doors open to reveal TENGTU  HOK, flanked by two uniformed Japanese Soldiers and a rob Chinese Advisor. He wears a fantastic gold ornamental rob Despite the majesty, however, nothing can disguise the fa that Hok is basically a wild, fat barbarian; an animal. H and his escort group bow in what is the beginning of a lo welcoming ceremony. The Germans exchange impatient glance but decide they should play it as it comes. They bow.
sense_profile: a fantastic gold ornamental rob Despite the majesty

text: No person in sight. Instead, we see a magnificent display ancient artifacts. Glass cases hold the velvet-couched pi at random spots on the shining marble floor. We hear an o sound. Near the floor on the rear wall of the museum, a s ventilation grate moves. A hand slides it gently across t marble. Indy sticks his head out and looks around.

The three Germans are being served tea and exotic delicac A pleased Tengtu Hok watches from a throne-cushion. When tray of tiny delicacies is presented to him, he takes a  massive handful, crushing them together on their way to h smiling mouth.

A huge golden gong, seven feet in diameter, is suspended  from the ceiling by a hook. An enormous hammer hangs pois above it, from which emanate myriad tiny threads which ru up and across the ceiling, then down to the various displ cases. Indy looks up at the gong, then continues his quic quiet foray among the cases. Beyond him, a high window.
Hok and his visitors stand to go. The German's pleased  expressions make it clear they're finally on their way to the museum.

Indy arrives at his destination. The lovely, carved gold  section of the headpiece is nested on purple velvet in a  glass case. At the bottom of the piece is a round hollow  where the staff would fit. There is a grunting sound behi Indy and he spins, already reaching for his revolver. A fierce Japanese Samurai is running at Indy full speed d an aisle of display cases. His sword is raised over his  shoulder ready to cut Indy in half. He's six feet away wh Indy's gun levels and fires twice, blasting him backwards Indy is still looking over his gun when another samurai s comes down from the side and knocks the pistol brutally o of Indy's grip; his hand avoids amputation by a quarter o an inch. An amazed Indy backs away from the crossing aisle as the  Second Samurai steps in to face him, sword raised. Indy b away into an open space and his bullwhip appears in his h He gives it one savage CRACK! to announce its arrival and the Samurai slows down, eyeing it curiously. The Samurai  does not look unhappy about this confrontation. How pure is - The Sword versus The Whip.

Tengtu Hok and the Germans have obviously heard something They are hurrying along the walkway at the side of the  building, Hok in the lead. Up ahead is the foot bridge wh crosses from the palace to the museum entrance over a moa
sense_profile: from the palace to the museum entrance over a moa

location: STREET IN FRONT OF THE PALACE

text: The Lovely Mercedes limousine blows up.
The Germans spin toward the blast. Drawing weapons, they back to investigate. Hok follows them, confused.

Indy and the Samurai face each other. They're both breath hard from previous, no-contact passes at each other. Now  Indy begins swinging the whip over his head again. It whi out toward the Samurai's face. The Samurai takes two ligh quick cuts at the leather, but misses. Indy swings for th Samurai's feet; the Japanese jumps nimbly, slashing at th whip. Indy does it again. The Samurai hops it. Once more. The Samurai is concentrating on hopping it. Indy sees it. The split second he wants. The whip flashes from the floor and wraps solidly and irrevocably around t Samurai's neck. Indy gives it a murderous pull and the Sa is dead on his feet.
sense_profile: swinging the whip over his head again
two ligh quick cuts at the leather

text: Hok and the three Germans are looking down at the flaming remains of the Mercedes. A look of concern crosses Hok's  face. He turns and runs back toward his beloved museum.

Indy is at the case containing the headpiece. He smashes glass with a samurai sword, reaches in and grabs the piec Immediately, behind him, the huge hammer falls and the so of the gong thunders through the museum.

At the sound of the gong, the running Hok skids to a halt with a crazed expression on his face. He disappears for t seconds in an alcove and emerges holding a big, black Tho Submachine Gun. He runs across the foot bridge and is jus barely over it when it blows up. Hok, safe, looks behind in amazement and then turns to the museum.

The double doors at the entrance slam open to reveal Hok. Indy is halfway along an unprotected wall back to his  ventilation entry route. Hok opens up on him, cutting off his retreat. Indy jumps behind a marble column, which is  promptly blasted with machine gun fire. Indy looks above him, sees the giant disk of the gong.  Reaching up, pushing with tremendous effort, he maneuvers off the hook. It bounces down to the floor on its side,  chipping the marble with its monstrous weight. Indy stead it and then puts his whole body into rolling it across th room toward the window. As it starts to roll, Indy slips  behind it and runs across the room with it. Hok can see the rolling gong. He opens up on it. The vici cacophony of machine gun fire is joined by the musical re of bullets hitting the gong and ricocheting away. Very, v noisy. Behind the gong, Indy gauges his move. As the gong is abo to be stopped by a marble bench, Indy talks a long stride onto the bench and dives through the glass of the high wi Hok's bullets hit the wall.
sense_profile: The double doors at the entrance slam
the giant disk of the gong
into rolling it across th room toward the window
As the gong is abo to be stopped by a marble bench
through the glass of the high wi Hok 's bullets
dives through the glass of the high wi Hok 's bullets

text: Indy lands in a shower of glass on the jutting roof of th museum's first floor. He rolls to a crouch and is immedia being fired upon. The Germans, cut off from the museum, a standing on the palace walkway firing at him. Indy takes fast for the rear of the museum.

Kehoe, craning to locate Indy, has the Ford rolling slowl along the back of the museum. Bang scouts from the back s Indy appears on the roof at a run, gauges the movement of the car and jumps from the roof of the museum to the roof the sedan. Unfortunately, the roof of the old car can't t it and Indy's legs knife right on through to the interior where he scares the hell out of Kehoe.
sense_profile: from the roof of the museum

text: Indy squirms his way down into the front seat.
Jesus! Are you all right!
(he's felt better) Great. Got it.
Kehoe guns it, throwing Indy back against the cushions.
What now?
I've got to get to Nepal.
The plane flies west into the sunset.
Under a meager seat light, Indy is pouring over a journal article by Abner Ravenwood and related map of Nepal. A few rows back, across the aisle, a trenchcoated Europea Spy eyes Indy.

A huge stuffed raven, wings spread wide, is mounted behin the long bar in the noisy, crowded saloon. A lively mix o patrons is represented in the late hour tableau: Nepalese natives, fierce Sherpa mountain guides, sleazy internatio smugglers and fugitives, and, of course, mountain climber from every corner of the earth. A tall Nepalese, MAHDLO, the bartender. In a corner near the fireplace trouble breaks out suddenl between the groups at two neighboring tables. Ferocious  representatives from each table - one a wild-looking SHER the other a muscular Australian CLIMBER - jump up to face each other. As the two contenders stand poised for action their respective supporters shift in their places, fondli lethal ice axes and clubs.
sense_profile: Ferocious representatives from each table - one a wild - looking SHER

text: Gmoiska! Shurga rintoik!
Aye! That'll be your last word.

The bar has quieted ominously and so we hear with startli clarity when - a door behind the bar slams open with a hu BANG! and some Presence, too small to be seen as it moves through the forest of towering patrons, makes a beeline f the troubled corner of the bar. A path clears for it. The Sherpa and the Climber are about to kill each other w the Presence arrives directly between them: she is MARION RAVENWOOD, twenty-five years old, beautiful, if a bit har looking. At this moment, however, that look does not hurt She is not intimidated by the combatants; she jabs accusa fingers into their chests. She is angry as hell. The patr shrink under her gaze.
sense_profile: through the forest of towering patrons
small to be seen as it moves through the forest of towering patrons
a beeline f the troubled corner of the bar

text: That does it! I've been patient with  you no-goods long enough. I'm not  open at 2 o'clock for myself, you  know. It's all for you. And how do  you repay me: Trouble and noise and  blood on my floor! I won't have it.  Everybody out! Out! Out! We're closed.  Closed! Do your killing outside! And  don't leave any bodies on the porch!

The place clears quickly. Stragglers and grumblers are gi special attention by Marion and Mahdlo, who has come from behind the bar carrying a big axe handle. Mahdlo herds th crows out the front door as Marion turns and walks behind the bar. A scowl on her lovely face, she has just begun clearing t bar of glasses when she notices one remaining Patron hudd over a glass at the far end of the bar. Grimacing in  exasperation, she heads that way like a locomotive.
sense_profile: one remaining Patron hudd over a glass at the far end of the bar

text: Hey you, deaf one! I said out of my  place. I don't mean next Easter, I  mean now -
She is almost on him when Indy looks up smiling. Marion s stares, shocked.
Hello, Marion.
She hits him with a solid right to the jaw, knocking him the barstool on the floor. He rubs his jaw and smiles up her.
Nice to see you, too.
Get up and get out.
(getting up) Take it easy. I'm looking for your  father.
(bitterly) Well you're two years too late.

Indy's attitude changes instantly. This is sad news. He i silent for a long time. Mahdlo comes in the front door an hurries forward when he sees Indy with Marion. He looks t her for guidance, but she stays him with a gesture.
Go home, Mahdlo. I'll see you  tomorrow.

Mahdlo is hesitant, but lays the axe handle on the bar an goes out. Indy has been barely aware of him. Now he settl again on the barstool. Marion has a vindictive look. She' let him stay, but she wants to inflict as much pain as  possible.
sense_profile: on the bar an goes out
to inflict as much pain as possible

text: What happened?
Avalanche. Up there. He was digging.  What else? He spent his whole life  digging. Dragging me all over this  rotten earth. For what?
Do you find him?
Hell no. He's buried where he was  working. Probably preserved real  good, too. In the snow.
Suddenly the hardness cracks. She is on the verge of tear and does not want him to see them. She turns away and tak a whiskey bottle from the shelf, then turns back to pout  herself a drink.
Not a bad way to go. Doing what he  loved.

(vitriolic) Don't give me that stuff! What do  you know? (she takes a drinks) I'm the one that was left in a bad  way. He didn't have a penny. Guess  how I lived, Mister Jones. I worked  here. And I wasn't the bartender. (another swallow) Finally the guy that owned the joint  went crazy. Snow crazy. They took  his away screaming. As they dragged  him out, he said the place was all  mine for life.
She looks around the saloon.
Can you imagine a more evil curse? (pause) So far, it's working.
Why not leave? Go back to the States.

I'll go back. I'll get there. Not  that there's a soul there who knows  my name or cares. But I'll go. And  when I do, they'll know me. 'Cause  I'm going to go back in style. With  money. A goddamn lady!
Where you gonna get it?
If I knew that, you think I'd still  be running this dive?
Indy looks at her, thinking. Under his gaze, she blushes, for reasons only she understands. She looks into her glas and, for a moment, she softens.

I'll tell you something Indy. I've  learned to hate you in the last ten  years. But somehow, no matter how  much I hated you, I always knew that  someday you'd come through that door.  I never doubted that. Something made  is inevitable. (hopefully) Why are you here... now... tonight?
Indy takes a long time to answer.
I need one of the pieces your father  collected.
Marion's eyes go icy. She swings at him again with her ri but this time he catches her at the wrist. Then he stops left, which she has brought up to slap him.
sense_profile: which she has brought up to slap him

text: You son-of-a-bitch! You know what  you did to me, to my life? This is  your handiwork.
I never meant to hurt you.
I was a child!
You knew what you were doing.
I was in love.
I guess that depends on your  definition.
It was wrong. You knew it.
Indy releases her arms.
Look, I did what I did. I don't expect  you to be happy about it. But maybe  we can do each other some good.
Why start now?
Shut up and listen for a second. I  want that piece your father had.  I've got money.
This stops her.
How much?
Enough to get you back to the States.  Where are his things?
Gone. I sold it all. It was all junk.  The junk he wasted his life on.
Everything?
Marion nods.
(giving up) That's too bad.
Indy feels tired, defeated. Marion is pleased.
You look disappointed. I like that.  How's it feel?
Indy has to smile at her glee.
(nods at his empty  glass) What are you drinking?
Seltzer.
(refilling his glass) Real man's drink. Me, I like scotch.  And I like bourbon. And vodka and  gin. I'm not much for brandy. I'm  off that.
She pours herself another as Indy watches, amused.
You're a tough broad now, aren't  you?
It's no act, pal. This ain't  Schenectady.
I can only say I'm sorry so many  times.
Marion looks at him thoughtfully, takes a drink.
You really have money? You don't  look rich. (Indy nods) I may be able to locate some of his  things. I know who's got them. What  do you want?
A bronze piece, about this size. In  the shape of the sun. Probably broken  off at the bottom. Has a little hole  in it, off-center. Does that sound  familiar?
Marion thinks, nods slowly.
Do you know where it is?
Maybe. How much?
Three thousand. American.
(negative) That'll get me back, but not in style.  This doodad must be pretty important.
Maybe.
A huge smile lights up Marion's face.
I knew it would happen eventually. I  knew it. Something had to go my way. (pours herself another  drink) I've got to think this out. I'm used  to bargaining with yaks.
Okay, five thousand. That's all I  can give you now. I can get you more  when you land in the States.
You word, huh? (Indy nods) Just like you said you'd be back  last time? That was your word too.
I'm back, aren't I?
Marion sneers and they smile together.
You can trust me.
Come back tomorrow.
Why?
Because I said so, that's why. It's  about time I called the shots in  this relationship.
Indy nods, gets up to go.
Wait a minute. Leave the five thousand  here. (Indy hesitates) You want trust, give some. I want to  smell your money.
Indy thinks about this a moment, then reaches inside his  shirt and pulls cash from a money belt. He lays five gran on the bar.
I trust you.
You're an idiot.
I've heard that.
Indy starts for the door. Marion takes another think. She getting high.
Hold it. Come here.
(moving back) Bossy, aren't you?
That's right. Give me a kiss.

Indy looks into her eyes, then leans over the bar and kis her deeply. When the kiss ends, their faces are very clos Marion is flushed. She liked it and would like more. She  raises her glass between them to discipline herself.
Get out of my place.
Indy smiles and walks to the front door. Then, without lo back -
Tomorrow.

He's gone. Marion stares after him, thinking. She takes a drink. Then slowly, her hand comes up to loosen the scarf that is draped around her throat. It falls away, revealin her graceful neck above the dipping top of her blouse. Ha there on a gold chain against her white skin is a sun-sha golden medallion. The bottom looks broken off. Marion lif the medallion so she can see it in her hand, then looks  thoughtfully after Indy.
sense_profile: to loosen the scarf that is draped around her throat

text: Indy sits thinking at the wheel of an old car. Finally, h puts the car in gear and drives away. Across the street, the shadow in a doorway comes to life. dark form steps out to look at Indy's departing car; it i the European Spy from the DC-3. He hurries off in the opp direction.
sense_profile: to look at Indy 's departing car

text: Marion stands before the fire that is shrinking in the  fireplace. She jabs at it abstractedly with a poker, thin Suddenly tears well up in her eyes. She lets the poker sl from her hand, wipes away the tears. She walks across the room to the end of the bar, still cluttered with bottles glasses, and stops at the pile of American money Indy has left. She takes the chain from around her neck and lets t medallion slide off it into her hand. She places it on th bar next to the pile of money, thinking. Then, having rea some decision, she picks up the pile of bills, walks up t back of the bar and pulls a small wooden box from under t bar. She flips open the top, puts the cash inside and clo the top. She leaves the box on the bar and starts back to the medallion. The front door of the saloon bursts open a Four Bad Men come in. Marion, halfway between the valuabl possessions and not wishing to draw attention to either,  stops where she is. The Four Bad Men who advance on her are: 1.) the obvious leader, a short, vile, sadistic German in spectacles by the name of BELZIG. 2.) a trenchcoated SECOND NAZI. 3.) a ratty-looking NEPALESE and 4.) a mean MONGOLIAN. The second NAZI and the MONGOLIAN b carry submachine guns.
sense_profile: before the fire that is shrinking in the fireplace
at the pile of American money
The front door of the saloon bursts
a Four Bad Men come in
The second NAZI and the MONGOLIAN b

text: Good evening, Fraulein.
The bar's closed.
We are not thirsty.

The Mongolian and the Nepalese poke around, checking to m sure there's no one else there. Down at the end of the bar, the medallion lies partially  hidden by surrounding glasses and bottles. The Second Naz stops very near it, but turns his back to it to face Belz and Marion.
What do you want?
The same thing your friend Dr. Jones  wanted. Surely he told you there  would be other interested parties.
Marion shakes her head.
Ah, the man is nefarious. I hope for  your sake he has not yet acquired  it.
Why, are you willing to offer more?
Almost certainly. Do you still have  it?
No. But I know where it is.

Belzig's smile fades at this news. He's not a patient sor Marion is chilled by the look. She turns and moves to the shelf of bottles behind her, reaching high for one, very  near the large stuffed raven. He hand lingers there a mom and we see - From an angle behind the stuffed raven, that the left win spread hides a Baretta automatic pistol. Marion's hand is very near it, but withdraws with only a whiskey bottle as the Mongolian walks toward her behind the bar. Marion opens the bottle before Belzig, who watches her  intently.
sense_profile: before Belzig , who watches her intently

text: How 'bout a drink for you and your  men?
The Second Nazi lights up at this suggestion. Belzig give him a withering look.
We will stick to the business at  hand, Fraulein.
(tough) Fine. Why don't you come back tomorrow  when Jones is here and we'll have an  auction?

Belzig gives her a cold look then turns and walks over to the fireplace. As soon as his back is turned, the Second  Nazi grabs the nearest whiskey bottle and takes a quick p In so doing, he leaves the medallion completely exposed.  Marion is aware of this as she looks at him. But he quick puts the bottle down again, obscuring the medallion, when Belzig speaks from the fireplace.
I'm afraid an auction is not possible. (pause) Your fire is dying here, Fraulein. (a beat, then  threatening) Why don't you tell us where the piece  is right now?
Listen, Herr Mac, I don't know who  you're used to dealing with, but no  one tells me what to do in my place.
Belzig, still looking in the fire, sneers and shakes his  head.
Americans! You're all alike. Fraulein  Ravenwood. I'll show you want I'm  used to.

He motions with his hand. The Mongolian moves up behind M and lifts her roughly over the top of the bar, knocking o bottles and spilling liquor. He deposits her on the other side, where the Nepalese and the Second Nazi flank her an hold her cruelly, arms behind her back. Marion raises a  ruckus. Belzig turns from the fireplace. In his hand is the poker its end glowing orange. He advances on Marion. Marion sto yelling, her eyes widen in terror.
Wait! I can be reasonable -
That time is passed.
The glowing poker point moves inexorably across the room  toward Marion's face.
You don't need that. I'll tell you  everything!
Yes, I know you will.

Belzig has no intention of stopping now. The glowing tip approaching Marion's face. The Nepalese watches with sava glee. The tip of the poker is five inches from Marion's nose wh there is a loud CRACK! and the fall of Indy's bullwhip wr around the middle of the poker and tears it out of Belzig hands. The poker sails high across the room, free of the  whip, and lands in the heavy curtains that cover one wind The curtains immediately burst into flame. The four Bad Men look in surprise toward the front entran Indy is poised there, the whip in his right hand, a .45  automatic raised toward them in his left.
Hello.

Now everything begins to happen very fast - The Mongolian had just come around the bar at the end opp the medallion. He dives back to crouch behind the end of bar, raising his submachine gun. Belzig and the Second German dive behind tables near the  bar. The Nepalese is slower to leave Marion, he draws a L Indy's .45 barks and the Nepalese dies spinning against t bar. Indy fires in the direction of the Mongolian. Marion swings up over the top of her bar. Belzig fires at her, but his bullets smash bottles behind the bar and thu into the raven. Marion flattens out on the floor behind the bar as bullet hit above her. She reaches up, snatches the axe handle fr where Mahdlo left it, and begins crawling down the length the bar toward - The Mongolian, who sticks his submachine gun out and fire blindly in Indy's direction. Indy is in a crouch behind a table, trying to get a shot someone. He doesn't notice in the din and confusion when door bursts open. An incredible, fearsome GIANT SHERPA, a seven feet tall, soars in and tackles Indy from behind. T whip flies from Indy's hand as he and the Giant Sherpa ro across the floor, upsetting furniture. The Mongolian, seeing this, stands up confidently. Marion rises behind him and bashes him over the head with the ax handle. He goes down and out. Fire has completely engulfed the curtains and is working  across the ceiling on decorative yak skin bunting. A burn fragment drops to the top of the bar, which immediately l up, fueled by the spilled alcohol. Full whiskey bottles  explode like Molotov cocktails. Rolling on the floor, Indy and the Giant Sherpa are fight for control of Indy's .45. Belzig sees this and shouts to the Second Nazi, who is rising from cover with submachine gun in hand.
sense_profile: the axe handle fr where Mahdlo left it
crawling down the length the bar toward - The Mongolian , who sticks his submachine gun out and fire blindly in Indy 's direction

text: Shoot them both!
He's our man!
Do as I say!

Both the Giant Sherpa and Indy hear this. The Giant Sherp exchanges an alarmed look with Indy and together they swi the .45 around toward the surprised Second Nazi. Two blas blow him away. That done, Indy brings a brass spittoon down on the Giant Sherpa's wrist and the .45 slides away. Indy jumps up and kicks the Giant Sherpa, who barely seems to feel it. He g Indy and flips him effortlessly onto a table. Belzig now has a clear shot at Indy. He raises his luger. Marion, at the end of the bar, finally gets the hand of t Mongolian's submachine gun. It roars to life in the gener direction of the ceiling. Belzig runs for cover as Marion gets control of the gun a levels it. Belzig dives around the end of the bar opposit Marion. When he has set himself, he peeks up over the edg of the scorched bar. The alcohol fire has moved down the and now, much to Belzig's surprise, he finds himself star at the fire-blackened sun-shaped medallion! His eyes widen. He cannot believe his good fortune. Witho hesitation he picks up the metal medallion, palming it.  Immediately there is a sickening searing sound and Belzig expression changes from joy to agony. He screams in pain tries to shake the red-hot medallion from his skin. Mario opens up and the bar starts to splinter in front of Belzi The medallion comes free of Belzig's hand and rolls acros the floor. Belzig has had enough. In excruciating pain, he turns, se a window, runs and dives through the glass. An exhausted Indy uses his whole body to upend the Giant  Sherpa, who lands hard on his back. They are surrounded b flames.
sense_profile: the Giant Sherpa , who barely seems to feel it
the hand of t Mongolian 's submachine gun
at the end of the bar
to life in the gener direction of the ceiling
himself star at the fire - blackened sun - shaped medallion
to shake the red - hot medallion from his skin
to splinter in front of Belzi

text: Belzig has his burned hand stuck deep in the snow. Now he withdraws it, steaming, and scurries off into the night l a wounded animal.

Marion throws down the empty submachine gun and moves thr the flames to the center of the bar where she left the bo with the five grand. She finds the remains of the box and its contents: a shapeless pile of ash and charred wood.
sense_profile: the empty submachine gun and moves
the remains of the box and its contents

text: Unbelievable!

At the end of the bar, the Mongolian has come back to lif He shakes out his head, then reaches inside his coat and  pulls out a Mauser pistol. Indy smashes a chair over the head of the Giant Sherpa an the huge creature goes down. The Mongolian points his Mauser through the smoke and fla at Indy. Suddenly, the Mongolian is shot dead. Marion stands beneath her stuffed raven with the Baretta. Indy moves quickly through the flames, his eyes scanning floor. He picks up his bullwhip and his crumpled felt hat He peers through the smoke till he spots Marion moving am the burning furniture.
Let's get out of here!
Not without that piece you want!
It's here?
Marion nods, kicks aside a burning chair. Another burning beam falls from the roof. Indy pulls Marion close to him  protectively.
Forget it! I want you out of here.  Now!
He begins dragging her out.
(pointing) There!
She breaks away from him, darts back and picks the hot  medallion up in the loose cloth of her blouse.
Let's go!
(looking around) You burned down my place!
(figuratively) I owe you plenty!
(literally) You owe me plenty!
(smiles) You're something!
I am something. And I'll tell you  exactly what -
She holds up the medallion possessively.
I'm your partner!

First we see the sprawl, the soaring minarets, the ancien skyline. Then we're closer, in the narrow, exotic streets teeming with life: fierce-looking men in tattered galabiy black-gowned women with veiled faces, ragged, barefoot  children.
sense_profile: the sprawl , the soaring minarets , the ancien skyline

text: Indy and Marion have been welcomed like family into the  crowded home of SALLAH, his wife FAYAH, and their NINE  CHILDREN (ages 4 - 18). Fayah, a huge, imposing woman,  appears, at first glance, to be the power in the house.  Sallah, a small, cheerful, energetic fellow in his fortie defers to his wife in all matters of little importance.  Suddenly the general liveliness at the children's table  escalates into pandemonium, attracting the attention of t adults.
Silence! (there is silence) Why do you forget yourselves?
The gaggle of grinning off-spring parts to reveal in thei midst - a MONKEY. It is munching some flat Arab bread.
What is this? Who brought this animal  in?

All the children chatter their innocence at once. The Mon chatters too; it's an entertainer. The Monkey jumps from children's table to the adults' and struts slowly up towa Marion, who thinks it's the cutest thing she ever saw. Wh it reaches her, it takes off its turban and does a deep,  grand bow to her. She is delighted and takes the Monkey i her arms. The Monkey kisses her cheek. The children laugh
sense_profile: it 's the cutest thing she ever saw

text: Why, thank you. I like you too.
Then it shall be welcome in our house.
Oh, no! You don't have to have it  around if you don't want it -
(cheerfully) All of Allah's creatures are welcome  here. You please us by letting us  please you.

Indy and Sallah sit in the small, protected courtyard. Sa holds the two sections of the headpiece, the medallion an the base, and has for the first time fitted them together They fit perfectly and complete the headpiece. He peruses the markings on the headpiece quizzically. Indy is cleani and loading a .45 automatic.
sense_profile: the two sections of the headpiece

text: I knew the Germans would hire you,  Sallah. They couldn't have an  excavation in the desert without the  best digger in Egypt.
All Arabs look alike to them, Indy.
Tell me about the map room at Tanis.
We found it three days ago. I broke  through myself.
Those Nazis are moving awfully fast.
The Frenchman is helping them.
Indy reacts.
Belloq. So he got away from the  Indians. This is going to be more  interesting that I thought.
I'm afraid this has put the Germans  close to finding the Well of the  Souls.
(indicates the  headpiece) Even Belloq won't be able to find it  without that. Can you make anything  of those markings? They're nothing  I'm familiar with.
(shakes his head "no") But I know someone who might. You  can go to see him tomorrow. (a worried expression) Indy... something bothers me.
What is it, my friend?
Sallah finds it hard to say. When he finally speaks, his  words are accompanied by a strange, eerie, foreboding rus of wind through the courtyard. Just a coincidence we migh suppose.

The wind dies down. Indy shakes off a chill and stares  thoughtfully at his friend.

A dark, smoke-filled den on iniquity. The patrons, almost all fearsome Arabs, sit in small shadowy groups around th room. Indy stands at the bar finishing off a fifth of bou He is drunk. The ARAB BARTENDER places a new bottle of  expensive bourbon in front of him. Indy eyes is queerly.

The Arab Bartender does a take, looking at the three, tou GERMAN HENCHMEN who have surrounded Indy from out of the  smoke, their hands stuffed in bulging trenchcoat pockets. Indy notices them now with a bleary glance. He decides he in no shape to kill or be killed and moves with them acro the room, taking his bottle with him. The Arab patrons ta this in and mind their own business. The occupant of the smoke-shrouded corner table becomes  visible only as Indy reaches there: it is Emile Belloq. H is drinking wine.
Belloq.
Good evening, Dr. Jones.
I ought to kill you right now.
It was not I who brought the girl  into this dirty business.
Indy knows its true; that's what's tearing him up.
Sit down, please, before you fall  down. We can behave as civilized  people. I'm afraid it will be your  last opportunity.
Indy sits, glancing at the German Henchmen, who settle ne just out of earshot.
Not a very private place for a murder.

(looking around) These Arabs will not interfere in  the white man's business. They do  not care if we kill each other off. (takes a sip of wine,  refers to it) Terribly difficult finding a decent  vintage here. You were quite vigorous  in Shanghai. Unfortunately, our friend  the Wild Boar had taken the precaution  of making several copies of the piece.
Indy registers this as he takes a drink. Belloq watches h with disdainful amusement.
How odd that is should end this way  for us, after so many... stimulating  encounters. I almost regret it. Where  shall I find a new adversary so close  to my own level?
Try the local sewer.
I know you despise me. We always  hate in others that which we most  fear in ourselves. And you and I are  very much alike.
Now you're getting nasty.

We have always done the same kind of  work. Our methods have not differed  as much as you pretend. I am a shadowy  reflection of you. But it would have  taken only a nudge to make you the  same as me, to push you out of the  light.
There's a certain amount of truth to this; the recognitio of it flickers across Indy's bleary eyes. Belloq sees it  there.
You know it to be true! How nice.  And how ironic the timing.
Belloq leans forward, eyes shining, voice suddenly differ
Do you realize what the Ark is? (very intense) It's a transmitter. A radio for  talking to God! And now it is within  my grasp.
What about your boss, der Fuhrer? I  thought he was waiting to take  possession.
Belloq glances into the gloom at the German Henchmen.
(quieter) When the time is right. When I am  finished with it.
I hope your friends are patient.  Dangerous work, Belloq.
Yes. Very. You may consider yourself  fortunate that your involvement  concludes here.
Tell me, did you get away with the  idol?
(negative) I was lucky to get away with my life.  The Hovitos proved quite narrow-minded  about the whole matter.
Indy takes a drink.
You know, if it's God you want to  talk to, maybe I can arrange it.
(smiles) You have not changed. But, please,  do not reach for your weapon until  you are ready to die.

(nods) Thanks you. (grave) Marion's dead.

Th room is lovely, with elaborate wall carvings and frescoes all lit by the bright stream of sunlight flooding in from above. This beam of light leads Indy's eye to the far end and the room's truly remarkable feature: built into the f in meticulous relief is a miniature stone model of the an city of Tanis. Already, the sunlight has worked its way d the far wall and is edging onto the miniature of the city On the floor, to the skylight side of the miniature, is a elaborate line created by embedded mosaic tiles. The even spaced slots in the line, each accompanied by a symbol of time of year, are for the base of the staff. Indy pulls t headpiece from his robes - it has been welded together - reaches for the staff.
An extremely nervous Sallah has the gathered rope in his  hands and is trying to appear casual as he inches back to the oil drum. There is now a good bit of activity going o up here.
Hey! You, the skinny one!
Sallah jumps about three feet. The JEEP GERMAN is standin in an open space ten yards away looking at Sallah.

Sallah gestures his innocence.

The Jeep German starts back toward his major concern: his jeep is stuck in some sand beyond the next tent. Some Ara Workers are trying in vain to budge it. He points to the kettle. Sallah looks frantically from th rope, back to the skylight of the map room, to the kettle food.
Now, idiot!

The moment has arrived. Even the tension of the circumsta cannot distract Indy from the purity of what he is about do. All his calculations are adjustments complete, Indy t the Staff of Ra and places it - CLINK! - in the right  depression on the base line. This is as active and exciti a moment as any archeologist can dream of and, at heart,  that is exactly what Indy is. The sunlight catches the ve top of the headpiece and moves within a fraction of an in of the tiny hole in its sun. The edge of the sunlight moving across the miniature city still a good two feet beyond the spot Belloq has settled And now that line of light is broken by the shadow of an  ornate sun at the top of the staff. Indy's face reflects his concentration. And then his imme pleasure. He sees what he came for. Out of the miniature city, one small building is being li by a tiny beam of sunlight in the center of the shadow of the metal sun. And by some trick of ancient artistry, thi one building responds to the sunlight like none of the ot The golden light permeates it: it seems to glow. The buil is in a direct line with Belloq's - all the Frenchman's o calculations were right - but it is a foot and a half bey it.
Sallah, sweating profusely, has finished serving the line Breakfasting Germans and now heads back to replace the ke and get away.
Water. Bring us water.

Indy is on his knees at the miniature city, a special tap measure in his hand. Indy has the tape strung from Belloq mistaken spot to his own correct spot. He gets his readin leaps up and crosses to the erect staff. He pulls the  headpiece off the staff and hides it in his robes. More waiting. Nothing. Indy looks around for some alterna means of escape. The room doesn't offer any. He looks up the skylight again.
(loudest) Sallah!

A long pause. Then something comes down. A makeshift rope Really just a bunch of clothing tied together - tunics, r pants. But what we see first and most prominently, the fi section of Indy's escape rope, is a bright Nazi flag. Ind beams and climbs.

Indy sticks his head out the skylight, sees it clear and  flops his body out. Sallah, crouching behind the oil drum immediately starts pulling in the makeshift rope. Sallah  stuffs the rope in the oil drum and the two men begin wak toward some tents.

Sallah glances at Indy, Then hurries back in that directi The Hungry German focuses on Indy.
Why aren't you at the digs? Come  here!

(yelling after him,  irritated) No, dummkopf, I said come!

text: Indy finds himself in a tent set up for rather comfortabl living. He has just started to cross it when he hears a l excited grunting. He turns toward the sound. In the corne tied to a chair and gagged is Marion. Indy rushes to her, snatches the gag from her mouth and embraces her. They ki deep and long.
I though you were dead.
They were throwing me around like a  rag doll.
They must have switched baskets.  Thank god for that! Bless those  bastards. Have they hurt you?
No. Not since I got here. They just  asked about you - what you knew. The  Frenchman's got the hot's for me.  I've been playing that along. Oh,  Indy, get me out of here.
Indy pulls out a knife and then stops suddenly, thinking.
What's wrong?
(putting the knife  away) I have to leave you here for a little  while. I know where the Ark is. If I  take you out of here they'll start  combing the place for us.
(louder) Cut me loose!
Keep your voice down.
(screaming) I said get me out of -
Indy pops the gag back in her mouth. Her eyes widen in fu and she grunts obscenities at him.

Look, you don't know how glad I am  to see you. And I don't like doing  this. But the whole thing will be  shot if you don't just sit here  quietly. They haven't hurt you in  the last twenty-four hours, they  aren't going to start now. I'll be  back to get you in no time.
He kisses her forehead, jumps up and hurries out of the t

Omar's truck is parked at the spot just viewed from afar. Dunes rise on either side. One of Omar's men has been pos as a lookout up on a ridge. Everybody else - Indy, Sallah Omar, and his men - have begun digging for the Wells of t Souls.
They continue to dig furiously, all of them drenched in s The hole has grown but this is slow, back-breaking work.

Belloq, SHLIEMANN the ranking Nazi, and Shliemann's Aide, GOBLER, come into the tent, which is full of charts and m drawings of the Ark, radio equipment, liquor and food. Th men have been out digging for the Well all day. They are  tired, discouraged, testy. In all matters, Gobler shows h alliance with Shliemann against Belloq with small looks a body language. The Frenchman has disappointed them and he feeling the isolation of a scapegoat. Belloq gets himself drink as Shliemann towels off his face.

text: I cautioned you about being premature  with that communique to Berlin.  Archeology is not an exact science.  If does not adhere to time schedules.
The Fuhrer is not a patient man. He  demands constant reports and he  expects progress. You led me to  believe -

Nothing. I have made no promises. I  said only that it looked very  favorable. Perhaps the Ark will still  be found in an adjoining chamber.  Based on the information in our  possession, my calculations were  correct. Perhaps some bit of evidence  still eludes us. Perhaps
Perhaps the girl can help us.
Belloq shoots him an angry look.
My feeling exactly. She was in  possession of the original piece for  years. She may know much. (really evil) If properly motivated...
I tell you, she knows nothing useful.
I'm surprised to find you squeamish.  That is not your reputation. But it  needn't concern you. I have the  perfect man for this kind of work.

Shliemann signals Gobler, who steps outside the tent a mo calls someone and then reappears. Belloq looks warily at entrance. After a moment Belzig enters, reeking villainy. When his eyes find Shliemann, his superior, he snaps a cr "Heil, Hitler!" at him, holding his palm rigid a long tim exposing a burned scar in the prefect shape of the sun  medallion.

In the eerie conjunction of moonlight and torchlight, Ind and the other men step back in awe of their discovery: th flush with the bottom of their pit, is a heavy stone entr door to an underground chamber. Special prying tools are  produced. With two men assigned to each of the two long t they work in unison to open the vault. They open it a foo and the other men rush in to flop the heavy door complete open. Down inside, only blackness. The men quickly prostrate themselves around the edge of t entry to look inside. Indy and Sallah each take a torch a hold them down the hole.

The Well of the Souls is a spooky chamber thirty feet dee The walls are covered with hieroglyphics and carvings. (after a long pause) Nothing. That is the way it is.
He watches her closely as she drains her glass and puts i down.
Did I ever say I was sorry I burned  down your tavern?
She turns so their lips are very close.
No. Then again, I burned up that  plane.
You saved my life.
And you saved mine.
Seems things have worked out kind of  even.
That's the way I like them.
Maybe we should consider all past  accounts closed.
Marion thinks about this a long time.
No. Not yet.
What else?
She looks into his eyes. A smile jumps from her lips to h He kisses her and they sink slowly to the cot.
The ship's rats are agitated. They tremble and chatter at the edges of the compartment, darting about. Out in the c of the hold, sitting all by itself, is the crated Ark. HU M-M.
Marion awakes with a start, alone in the cot. Something's wrong. The ship is quiet. Indy is strapping on his holste He pulls his ship and jacket from a hook.

I'm going to find out.
Indy runs toward the bow, then climbs some steps four at time. A MESSENGER PIRATE is hurrying to get him, but flie by him on the steps. By the time the Pirate stops himself Indy is gone.

Katanga turns quickly, pointing with a sweeping hand. Ind looks. Arrayed in a rough semicircle around the ship are German Wolf Submarines. All of their deck guns are manned and trained on the Bantu Wind. Worse, at least five heavi armed boarding parties in rafts are closing quickly on th ship.

(fast) I sent my man for you. You and the  girl must disappear. We have a place  in the hold. Go, my friend!

Indy flies down some stairs and starts to round a corner. Suddenly he throws himself backwards, out of view. Three  uniformed Nazis are clustered near a cabin door holding t Messenger Pirate. Now two more come out of the cabin tryi to maintain their grasp on a kicking, yelling Marion. She still wearing her white nightgown. More Nazis clamber ont the deck and head toward Indy, slamming open doors, roust Pirates, spouting racial epithets. Indy steps backwards a fades into the maze of the ship.

The ship is swarming with Nazis. The Black Pirates are he forward, subjected to rough physical and verbal abuse by Aryan Supermen. They'd  gladly give their lives to rip the throat out of a few Kr In the hold, the door slams open and Nazis pour in; they  smile at the sight of the crated Ark.

text: Take it aboard the Wurrfler!

Jones is dead.

We killed him. He was of no use to  us. The girl, however, has certain  value where we are headed. She will  bring a very good price. If that  cargo you have taken was your goal,  then go in peace with it. But leave  us the girl. It will reduce our loss  on this trip.
Savage. You are not in a position to  ask for anything. We will take what  we wish and then decide whether or  not to blow your ship from the water.

That girl goes with me. It will be  part of my compensation. I'm sure  the Fuhrer would approve.

If she fails to please me, you can  do with her as you wish.
This appeals to Shliemann's nature. He signals his agreem with a gesture. Belloq ushers Marion away with her two  keepers.
The Nazis have returned to their subs. Shliemann is on th bridge with the WURRFLER'S CAPTAIN and the Captain's Aide The Captain is an honorable career Navy man.
Colonel Shliemann, all torpedoes are  loaded.

Shliemann nods and continues to stare at the Bantu Wind, does the Captain. The Pirate crew is all lined across the bow. Towering above the others, standing on the rail, pro and defiant, is Katanga. Shliemann looks at the Wurrfler' Captain a moment.
What do you think, Captain?
(earnestly) I think not, Colonel. Nothing is to  be gained. We are not at war.
Shliemann mulls this, then turns to the hatch.
...yet. Let the vermin live. We must  be on our way.

Shliemann disappears down the hatch. The Captain is very  pleased. A Radioman speaks into his headset, then follows the other Aides down the hatch. In the distance the other subs begin to move away from the ship. The Captain, alone the bridge, looks once more at Katanga. On the Bantu Wind, Katanga executes what might be taken f a salute. The Wurrfler's Captain smiles, salutes crisply, then goes below, pulling the hatch closed. Immediately, the Wurrfle begins to move. And as it does, we see the rail at the af of the main deck. From nowhere, a wet sleeve appears and hand grabs the rail! Indy pulls his dripping body onto the sub's main deck. He has lost his felt hat once and for all. Other than that, outfit is the same as always, just wetter. Suddenly, wate is washing over his feet; the Wurrfler is beginning to  submerge. Indy runs through quickly deepening water towar the haven of the conning tower. Halfway there, he slips a goes down. Only by grabbing the base of the aftmast light does he keep from being swept away. He struggles to his f and sloshes through knee-deep water to the base of the co tower. Indy climbs the ladder to the bridge of the conning tower and looks down. The water is rising toward his fast. Indy climbs the ladder to the top of the turret and braces him between the two uprights there - the 7 foot radio mast an the 20 foot periscope. Still the ocean comes up to meet h Soon the top of the turret is under water and the radio m is disappearing. text: The sun warms that part of his body Indy has contrived to keep out of the water. The rest floats out behind. Indy i comfortable, but all in all, it's not as terrible as he m have feared.
It's as terrible as Indy might have feared. He looks wast Waterlogged and exhausted. The wet leather of the whip is contracting and he must struggle constantly to keep it fr cutting into his skin.
Several shark fins cut the surface, appearing and disappe in the bright moonlight. They are shadowing -
Indy looks through barely open eyes at the sharks running alongside. There is nothing to be done. His eyes close.

The submarine has stopped. The water is calm. The moon is bright. A gentle swell splashes Indy awake. He blinks, tr to regain his senses. He makes an inventory of his body.  Surprised to find himself intact, his spirits lift. Some  hidden reserve of energy flows through him. He frees his  aching arms from the wet leather of his whip, leaving onl one loop around his waist to hold him to the sub. He rubs his hands and stretches. Once again, he has survived. To  fight again. He looks around.

A lovely island. No sign of man's presence. The sub has  stopped at the mouth of a wide cove completely ringed by  tall white rock cliffs. Suddenly the sub begins to move a It is headed directly toward the center of the cliffs. In holds on, mystified, alert. When the cliffs are very clos the sub begins to dive.
Damn!
He thinks hard. Inspiration hits just before the water. I flips his leather jacket up over his head and holds the j out in front of him. His head is hidden by the jacket as goes under water.

The sub enters an underwater tunnel that penetrates into cliffs. Indy is held to the periscope by his crossed legs and the whip. His impromptu air bubble is working, but it a struggle to maintain it. The sub begins to cut through think marine vegetation. Ea dangling growth pulls at Indy's body and slaps at his lea bubble. Now a clump of entwined seaweed rips the leather of his hands and his bubble of air rises away. Indy hangs on, holding his breath, but the vegetation gets denser.  Finally, it pulls him off the periscope. The sub moves on disappearing ahead. Indy rises desperately through the dark water, his hand  outstretched. Then, almost simultaneously, hand and head solid rock. But no air. Indy feels along the ceiling of r Nothing. It's all submerged. Indy dives, stroking deep into the tunnel. When he has  descended 15 feet, he grabs a vine and steadies himself. eyes search the dim roof of the tunnel. He sees his last  hope in the distance - a small blue circle, an air pocket He swims for it. In the air pocket, Indy's head breaks the surface and sma into rock again. The pocket is only six inches deep. No  matter. Indy loves it. He'd like to move in. He gulps air
